post_text: Our students are able to come into the school for face to face support along with picking supplies for projects while working virtually. This week our students in Environmental Science are making a Pond Ecosystem in a Bottle. They will create 3 separate but connected chambers: aquatic, decomposition and terrestrial. The aquatic chamber will have fish, snails and seaweed in water. The decomposition chamber will have soil, worms, pill bugs, leaves, grass and decomposing fruit and vegetable remains. The terrestrial chamber will have dirt, worms and seeds planted in it. The students will collect data and learn about interactions between the Earth's biosphere, atmosphere, geosphere and hydrosphere.

August 18 at 1:18 PM ·

A public charter school in the USA, Morey FlexTech High School-Shepherd, which is focused on project-based learning, has been introducing sociocracy into their school.

Will Gowen, their social studies teacher, is leading the movement as the coordinator of sociocratic and democratic initiatives in the school since 2018.

They have established a "School Circle" where students can meet, share thoughts, discuss issues and develop proposals to influence their school together.

Talking about the School Circle, one student's feedback was: "It gives you more than one point of view on topics and it shows you how your idea might affect the whole school."

post_text: In Food Ed, our students were studying food taboos. We looked at foods around the world that might be considered taboo in some places, but are widely eaten or acceptable in others. We spent many days researching different foods and paid special attention to the eating of insects because there are some scientists and chefs that believe that this is our food future. Insects are able to be raised in less space, provide more protein per pound, and are better on the environment when "raised" in large quantities. Students then got to experience trying some of the insects that they did research on and watched documentaries on.

The Blues to Rock and Roll Mural was created as a part of the Soundtrack of America class in Fall 2018. The mural shows the evolution in American Popular Music focusing on the evolution of Blues to Rock music. Some themes the mural touches on includes how blues music traveled with 'The Great Migration' from Mississippi to Chicago (and other northern cities), how blues music evolved to Rhythm & Blues (R&B) once in northern cities, and how blues influenced the growth of major Rock and Roll superstars including The Beatles and Elvis Presley.
List of Musicians Portraits in order (left to right):
Muddy Waters, Howling Wolf, and B.B King - Blues
LaVern Baker - Rhythm and Blues (R&B)
Johnny Cash, Chuck Berry, and Elvis Presley - Rock and Roll
The background colors represent the main music genres we covered in our class. Blue for Blues, purple for R&B, and red for Rock.
